tei:msContents.tei:summary: Inscription from the sanctuary of Pietrabbondante recording a dedication by the meddix tuticus N. Vesulliaeus

tei:layout.tei:note: The inscription is engraved on the lower part of the block. On its upper part was previously engraved an inscription erased in antiquity (ItAnt Oscan 4).

tei:handNote.tei:note: Words are separated by dots. Use of letters in ligature: nv at l. 1; ík, ak and ar at l. 3; aík at l. 6.

tei:provenance.tei:placeName: Found near the theater, at the foot of the slope where the stage is located

tei:encodingDesc.tei:p: Marked-up according to the EpiDoc Guidelines

tei:div.tei:p: Nuvio Vesulliaeo figlio di Trebio, meddix tuticus, questo santuario dedicò/edificò (o sim.) da (?) Boviano / con argento bovianese

tei:desc.tei:ref: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International license – (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0).

tei:div.tei:p: Nuvius Vesulliaeus son of Trebius, meddix tuticus, this sanctuary dedicated/built (or sim.) from (?) Bovianus / from Bovianensian (money)

tei:desc.tei:ref: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 license.

tei:note.tei:p: Crawford, ImIt 2011, supposes that this text is probably related to the erased inscription ItAnt Oscan 4, the stone carring both of them.

The meaning of the ablative búvaianud is problematic. Its understanding as a complement of place (see La Regina 1966), referring to the place where the sanctuary is located or where the magistrate held his position, does not conform satisfactorily to the meaning of the text (see Marchese 1998).

The word could also indicate the community on behalf of which the magistrate acts: "on behalf of the community of Bovianum". The use of the ablative case of a place name used in the latter meaning is not documented elsewhere.

Lejeune 1972: 102–5, proposed to interpret búvaianud as an adjective, referring to an implicit noun meaning 'money' (see also Crawford, ImIt, 2011: 1175). This hypothesis is unlikely for several reasons (see Prosdocimi 1996: § 3.4.2.).

Differently from all previous editors, Crawford, ImIt, 2011: 1175 establishes a reading akdafed, thinking "that the apparent diacritical here is accidental damage". A possible form akdafed, instead of the problematic aíkdafed, had already been hypothesized by Prosdocimi 1996: § 3.4.2.
However, from our autopsy no substantial differences emerge from the other í present in the text.

The semantics of the verb aíkdafed is contested and still debated. On the basis of the context and etymology, the verb certainly refers to the semantic field of 'to give, to dedicate', or similar (see Prosdocimi 1996: § 3.4.2. and Marchese 1998).

The verb has traditionally been interpreted as a building-verb meaning '(he) built' or, following La Regina 1980: 32, 'he decreed to build'. This interpretation overcomes the difficulty of considering Bovianum as the place where the sakaraklúm was located, but of considering it rather as the place where the decision to construct the temple was made, since Pietrabbondante cannot be identified with Bovianum
Crawford, ImIt 2011: 1175, following Lejeune 1972, translates 'added from B. money', suggesting that the community of Bovianum funded the project, without deciding how the money would have been used.
For a summary of the socio-historical issues related to this inscription, see Scopacasa 2015: 219-222.
